timeline.bodyText: Let's run this in a separate PR to get feedback (if any) on this.
timeline.author: findepi

replies.bodyText: This is required for the next change. This config was added in ancient times for no good reason. I can get it merged first if you’re concerned.
replies.author: electrum

timeline.author: findepi

replies.bodyText: There are two underscores with this change (the class code adds one). We added three here to separate when there were two versions (now there is only one). I’m fine making it longer, but it didn’t seem necessary.
replies.author: electrum

replies.bodyText: I updated this to match your suggestion.
replies.author: electrum

timeline.author: findepi

replies.bodyText: This is standard formatting. You can find thousands of examples of this in the code base. You can also find plenty without braces. I usually write them for and/or for clarify and visual separation.
replies.author: electrum

replies.bodyText: I checked and we actually have far more without parentheses, so I will change this.
replies.author: electrum

timeline.bodyText:
revert the rename, this is going to be annoyance for developers within the community (all the saved launch configurations...)
call the new class simply Main
timeline.author: findepi
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -39,7 +39,7 @@ After opening the project in IntelliJ, double check that the Java SDK is properl
 
 Presto comes with sample configuration that should work out-of-the-box for development. Use the following options to create a run configuration:
 
-* Main Class: `io.prestosql.server.PrestoServer`
+* Main Class: `io.prestosql.server.Server`

replies.bodyText: add some summary of changes (and purpose) to the Run PrestoServer main on Java 8 for version check commit, or split it up, as the purpose is hard to infer from the diff.
replies.author: findepi

replies.bodyText: No, keeping the class name is intentional as it shows up in jps and other JVM tools. Minimizing the administrator visible changes outweighs the minor developer inconvenience (it’s one change of the class name your IDE run configuration — we had a far larger change when we moved all the tests to a new package).
replies.author: electrum

replies.bodyText: Good idea, I added a commit description. The purpose is to fail with a friendly error message rather than unsupported class file version.
replies.author: electrum

timeline.bodyText:
Build server for Java 11

Maybe add to cmt msg some hint that requiring Java 11+ for compilation (of every module) is conscious choice.
timeline.author: findepi
findepi

replies.bodyText: This was intentional so the message would be (found null) instead of (found ). In practice, this should be impossible anyway, so I'll change it to your suggestion.
replies.author: electrum

timeline.bodyText:
Can the sys prop return sth like 11.0.3?
(then we would get null here)
timeline.author: findepi

replies.bodyText: Thanks, I somehow dropped the split on . when refactoring this.
replies.author: electrum

timeline.bodyText:
Add a comment that this main method is for developers' only.
In fact, maybe we remove this method at all?
We could change README -- instead of changing the class name, you could change the module name to use the new module.
timeline.author: findepi

replies.bodyText: We'd have to move the etc directory as well, but that seems better. I was thinking this would be a temporary change, but it seems good to keep this special main method around to provide a good error message when we update the JVM requirement.
replies.author: electrum

timeline.message: Update TestJmxHistoricalData for newer Java versions

Build server for Java 11

All modules, except for CLI, JDBC, and their dependencies, now
require Java 11+ for compilation and can take advantage of such
language and JDK features.

Run PrestoServer main on Java 8 for version check

This allows failing with a proper error message if run using Java 8
rather than the JVM failing with "unsupported class file version".
